text: [Music] welcome to the drive podcast i'm your host peter attea if you like this video please let me know by subscribing to the channel or visiting my website to become a member for more exclusive content [Music] what was the first thing you saw in frc which maybe we should take a step back and explain what frc is after you maybe explain the first thing you saw but i want to spend some time understanding this because it's one of the many systems you now bring into what you do and how you coach right um i think the biggest thing was like you can't go where you don't know right so if if you're working on in-range joint control explain what that is so we like to live life in our mid-range so it's very comfortable there we're very used to being there um but if you think of like overhead flexion like you're in range would be way back here but you probably have more than that depending on a lot of situations but if you're so used to going just here over and over and over again and you're really able to go here this is the area you don't know or the area you can't control and the whole thing is like control yourself so um it was interesting to me you don't think about you don't if you don't use it you lose it so you know our cyst our brain our central nervous system is quite a lazy one and if you don't kind of remind yourself where your end ranges are you'll stop going there i'll digress for a moment to tell a story about the first time you exposed me to this do you know which story i'm gonna tell i have no idea um it was doing a tricep kickback at end range and how many pounds
title: Functional Range Conditioning (FRC) & Training End Range | Peter Attia, M.D. & Beth Lewis

text: well you went you went to the dumbbell rack and you got a five pound dumbbell and i remember you walking back to me and i was thinking i wonder what she's going to do with that other than like i literally door open yeah yeah like i i wouldn't even hold the door open like what could you possibly be doing with a five pound dumbbell and then you had me get down on my hands and knees and maybe we'll even demonstrate this exercise afterwards because we're gonna this podcast will be accompanied by a great video but you had me do basically what amounted to a tricep kickback but at end range so full shoulder extension um you know accompany with scapular retraction depression yeah and i think i got to seven reps before my triceps seized and i couldn't do anything right right and i just i just couldn't imagine that that muscle which you know ostensibly is strong in its mid-range oh yeah could be so weak and deconditioned at its end range right i mean you have to think you're like you're in maximum stretch on the opposite side and you're having to control that length with the regressive side the opposite side and it's your weakest at your end range yeah just show people the position i'm in from explain all the terms you just said so we talked about scapular position retraction yep and then depression extension or yeah shoulder extension and then you're adding load onto that with elbow extension yeah and again with five pounds with five pounds so most people i do that body weight first and they're like so i should feel pretty good about myself yes totally a thousand percent i was so annoyed by that and then the next day i just went to the eight pounds and you were like you're such an idiot like now you're doing it incorrectly
title: Functional Range Conditioning (FRC) & Training End Range | Peter Attia, M.D. & Beth Lewis

text: you're you know right because when you're working in range you have to actually hold in range if it drops out of it then you've lost it and to really get in touch with the mechanoreceptors like you have to be on n range it's a stimulus that your brain wants um but it won't it won't fire to it it won't pay attention to it unless you're actually on in range [Music]
